speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will begin with an overview of economic conditions and an explanation of the decisions the Committee made at today’s meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I have one overarching goal: to sustain the economic expansion, with a strong job market and stable prices, for the benefit of the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The U.S. economy is in a good place, and we will continue to use our monetary policy tools to help keep it there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The jobs market is strong, showing healthier wage gains and prompting many people to join or remain in the workforce.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate is near historic lows, and inflation remains near our 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We continue to expect that the American economy will grow at a solid pace in 2019, although likely slower than the very strong pace of 2018.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We believe that our current policy stance is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since last year, however, we have noted some developments at home and around the world that bear close attention.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Given the overall favorable conditions in our economy, my colleagues and I will be patient in assessing what, if any, changes in the stance of policy may be needed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let me explain in more detail how incoming data warrant our current stance and a wait-and-see approach to changes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With the benefit of fiscal stimulus and other tailwinds, growth in 2018 was strong—in fact, at 3.1 percent, the strongest year in more than a decade.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For some time, most forecasts have called for growth to continue in 2019 at a somewhat lower but still healthy pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For example, last September, Committee participants saw growth coming in at about 2.5 percent this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Data arriving since September suggest that growth is slowing somewhat more than expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Financial conditions tightened considerably over the fourth quarter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While conditions March 20, 2019 have eased since then, they remain less supportive of growth than during most of 2018.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Growth Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL has slowed in some foreign economies—notably, in Europe and China.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While the U.S. economy showed little evidence of slowdown through the end of 2018, the limited data we have so far this year have been somewhat more mixed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Unusually strong payroll job growth in January was followed by little growth at all in February.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Smoothing through these variations, average monthly job growth appears to have stepped down from last year’s strong pace, but job gains remain well above the pace necessary to provide jobs for new labor force entrants.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many other labor market indicators continue to show strength.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Weak retail sales data for December bounced back considerably in January but, on balance, seem to point to somewhat slower growth in consumer spending.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Business fixed investment also appears to be growing at a slower pace than last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation has been muted, and some indicators of longer-term inflation expectations remain at the low end of their ranges in recent years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Along with these developments, unresolved policy issues, such as Brexit and the ongoing trade negotiations, pose some risks to the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Much of the discussion at our meeting focused on what we should make of the varied indicators.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today’s Summary of Economic Projections, the SEP, reflects the assessments of individual Committee participants.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And these views are in line with a broad range of other forecasts and point to a modest slowdown, with overall conditions remaining favorable.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: FOMC participants sought—now see 2019 growth at roughly 2 percent, with the unemployment rate remaining below 4 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Core inflation, which omits the effects of volatile food and energy prices, remains close to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Declines in oil prices since last fall are expected to push headline inflation below 2 percent for a time, but this effect is likely to be temporary.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, I’m March 20, 2019 describing views of the most likely outcomes, but historical experience reminds us that growth Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL and inflation this year could be stronger or weaker than what we now project.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The federal funds rate is now in the broad range of estimates of neutral—the rate that tends neither to stimulate nor to restrain the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I noted, my colleagues and I think that this setting is well suited to the current outlook and believe that we should be patient in assessing the need for any change in the stance of policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: “Patient” means that we see no need to rush to judgment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It may be some time before the outlook for jobs and inflation calls clearly for a change in policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In discussing the Committee’s projections, it’s useful to note what those projections are, as well as what they are not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The SEP includes participants’ individual projections of the most likely economic scenario, along with their views of the appropriate path of the federal funds rate in that scenario.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Views about the most likely scenario form one input into our policy discussions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also discuss other plausible scenarios, including the risk of more worrisome outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These and other scenarios and many other considerations go into policy but are not reflected in projections of the most likely case.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thus, we always emphasize that the interest rate projections in the SEP are not a Committee decision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They are not a Committee plan.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As Chair Yellen noted some years ago, the FOMC statement, rather than the dot plot, is the device that the Committee uses to express its opinions about the likely path of rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today the Committee released Balance Sheet Normalization Principles and Plans—revised Balance Sheet Normalization Principles and Plans.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have long said that the size of the balance sheet will be considered normalized when the balance sheet is once again at the smallest level consistent with conducting monetary policy efficiently and effectively.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have sought to make the normalization process transparent, predictable, and gradual in order to minimize March 20, 2019 disruption and risks to our dual-mandate objectives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today’s announcement is the result of Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL discussions over the past four FOMC meetings about how best to achieve these goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The plans have many technical details, and I’ll be happy to answer questions on those details.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, for now, I’ll summarize the key elements.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since October 2017, we have been allowing our asset holdings to decline by not reinvesting all of the payments we receive as securities matured or were prepaid.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today we announced that we intend to slow the runoff of our assets starting in May and to cease runoff entirely in September of this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In September, reserve balances may still be somewhat above the level required to conduct policy efficiently and effectively.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If this is so, we may hold the size of our asset holdings roughly constant for a time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: During this time, ongoing gradual increases in currency and our other nonreserve liabilities would imply very gradual declines in reserve balances.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When the Committee judges that reserves should not decline further, securities holdings will again begin to rise, as dictated by the growth of demand for our reserve and nonreserve liabilities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We believe that these plans will facilitate a predictable, transparent, and smooth process, and we will make additional adjustments if conditions warrant.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Committee will soon turn to a few remaining normalization topics, including the desired maturity composition of our portfolio of Treasury securities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We maintain our long-stated intention to return to a portfolio consisting mainly of Treasury securities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I will be glad to take your questions.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Heather Long from the Washington Post.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: On the broader economy, can you clarify how worried the FOMC is about a steep slowdown?

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Some of the actions today March 20, 2019 look like there is more worry.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: And on the balance sheet, can you clarify: Does the FOMC see Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the runoff as a form of monetary tightening?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on the outlook, our outlook is a positive one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I mentioned, FOMC participants continue to see growth this year of around 2 percent, just a bit below what we saw back in—at the end of last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And part of that is seeing that economic fundamentals—underlying economic fundamentals are still very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You have a strong labor market by most measures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You have rising incomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’ve got very low unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You have confidence surveys for households and also for businesses that are at attractive levels, and you also have financial conditions that are more accommodative than they were a couple of months ago.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we see the outlook as a positive one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As far as balance sheet—the balance sheet plan, the answer to that is, you asked whether that’s related to our monetary policy, in effect, and the answer is really “no.” We are—we still—we think of the interest rate tool as the principal tool of monetary policy, and we think of ourselves as returning the balance sheet to a normal level over the course of the next six months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re not really thinking of those as two different tools of monetary policy.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Steve Liesman, CNBC.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Mr. Chairman, can you talk about how global developments are affecting the U.S.?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: What’s the cause of the weakness over there?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: How much is it responsible for the downgrade in GDP over here?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: And what impact are tariffs, both in the United States and retaliatory tariffs, having on both the U.S. and the global economies?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the global economy was a tailwind for the United States in 2017.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That was the year of synchronized global growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we began 2018 expecting and hoping for more of the same.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What happened instead is that the global economy started to gradually slow, March 20, 2019 and now we see a situation where the European economy has slowed substantially—and so has Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the Chinese economy, although the European economy more.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And just as strong global growth was a tailwind, weaker global growth can be a headwind to our economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: How big is that effect?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s hard to be precise about it, but, clearly, we will feel that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is an integrated global economy, and global financial markets are integrated as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of what’s causing it, it seems to be a range of different things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In China, you have, you know, factors that are very specific to China.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The main point, though, is that, I would say, the outlook—let’s look at the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chinese authorities have taken many steps since the middle of last year to support economic activity, and I think the base case is that, ultimately, Chinese activity will stabilize at an attractive level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And in Europe, you know, we see some weakening, but, again, we don’t see—we don’t see recession, and we do see positive growth still.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You ask about tariffs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say, tariffs may be a factor in China.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think they’re the main factor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the main factors are the delevering campaign that the government undertook a couple of years ago and also just the longer-term slowing to a more sustainable pace of growth that economies find as they mature.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of our own economy, the level of tariffs is relatively small in the size of our economy—relative to the size of our economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have, since the beginning of the year—and before, really—been hearing from our extensive network of business contacts a lot of concerns about tariffs, concerns about material costs on imported products, and the loss of markets and things like that, depending on which industry, so there’s a fair amount of uncertainty.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s hard to say how much of an effect that’s having on our economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s very hard to tease that apart.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I will say, it’s been a prominent concern among our business contacts for some time now.

speaker: JAMES PUZZANGHERA
sentence: Hi.

speaker: JAMES PUZZANGHERA
sentence: Thank you, Chairman.

speaker: JAMES PUZZANGHERA
sentence: I want to switch gears temporarily to Wells Fargo.

speaker: JAMES PUZZANGHERA
sentence: Wells Fargo last week announced that its chief executive received a 5 percent pay raise last year, and this comes among continued settlements by the bank of various consumer abuse and reports that new consumer-unfriendly sales incentives are returning.

speaker: JAMES PUZZANGHERA
sentence: Do you have concerns about Wells Fargo’s efforts to fix its problems, and do you expect the asset cap to remain in place beyond this year?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Wells Fargo.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what happened at Wells Fargo really was a remarkably widespread series of breakdowns, really, in their risk-management apparatus, which resulted in significant consumer abuses, let’s say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And as it’s gone on and on, it’s become clear that—I think some time ago it became clear that these are deep problems that needed to be addressed in a fundamental kind of a way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s a lot of work to do on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we put in place, really, an unprecedented sanction in the form of an asset growth cap, and we will not lift that until Wells Fargo gets their arms around this, comes forward with plans, implements those plans, and we’re satisfied with what they’ve done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s not where we are right now.

speaker: JAMES PUZZANGHERA
sentence: Do you believe it’s appropriate—do you believe it’s appropriate for the CEO to be getting a pay raise in light of those conditions, in terms of corporate governance?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, our main supervisory focus is on the company fixing its risk-management approach and fundamentally rebuilding that approach.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t approve individual pay packages.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do supervise boards of directors for, you know, for having a set of compensation practices that don’t reward short-term risk-taking and that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we will supervise based on that.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Michael McKee with Bloomberg Radio and Television.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: I wonder if you could discuss the balance of risks.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: I know you said that the outlook among the Committee members is a positive one, but since the end of the meeting, the 3-month–10-year Treasury spread has fallen to 7 basis points, and now, according to fed funds futures trading, there’s a 50 percent chance of a rate cut by next January.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: How far off are the markets?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: What do you think the risks actually are?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, first, the data are not currently sending a signal that we need to move in one direction or another, in my view.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say it this way: We see a positive outlook for this year, a favorable outlook for this year, as I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in our SEP projections, Committee members, participants, generally see growth of around 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They see unemployment remaining below 4 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They see inflation remaining close to target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they see growth, as I said, around 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, that’s a positive outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a favorable outlook.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re also very mindful—and we have been, of course, all along—of what the risks are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you see—you mentioned some of them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, you see slowing global growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You still have—there’s no resolution of Brexit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s no resolution, really, of the trade talks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These are ongoing risks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re also carefully monitoring what’s happening with U.S. growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We called that out in our statement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the limited data that we have do show a slowdown.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: On the other hand, as I mentioned, we see the underlying economic fundamentals for growth this year as still very positive.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s really how we’re thinking about it.

speaker: JIM TANKERSLEY
sentence: Hi, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: JIM TANKERSLEY
sentence: Jim Tankersley, New York Times.

speaker: JIM TANKERSLEY
sentence: I’m curious, you’re now a full percentage point—actually, more than a percentage point—below the White House in your projections for growth this year.

speaker: JIM TANKERSLEY
sentence: By my calculations, that’s the largest spread March 20, 2019 we’ve seen since the end of the recession between the White House and the Fed.

speaker: JIM TANKERSLEY
sentence: Why, for one, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL do you see—do you think you see the economy so differently than they do, and do you worry at all about implications for policy from that?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I haven’t—I haven’t seen their projection.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t comment on their projection.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would take it this way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can think of growth as being composed of two things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And one is really growth in the workforce—more hours worked.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the other is productivity—it’s output per hour.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can really think of growth as those two things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ve been calling—often mentioning these days that it would be great if we had national-level policies to support higher labor force participation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The United States is now one of the lowest countries among the advanced economies, in terms of our labor force participation by prime-age workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s a place where we can grow faster.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If we can bring more people into the labor force and give them a chance to contribute to and benefit from our overall prosperity, that will be a great thing for the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would like to see that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Productivity is much harder.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s very difficult to project productivity over long stretches of time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a function of evolving technology.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I guess I would say, what is the potential growth rate?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s quite hard to know with any precision, and I just would like to see us, you know, undertake an effort to make it be as high as it can sustainably be.

speaker: JIM TANKERSLEY
sentence: A quick follow-up on that.

speaker: JIM TANKERSLEY
sentence: Do you see the tax cuts—the 2017 tax cuts as having provided a large boost to labor force participation as the White House does?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s clear that the tax and spending policies that were adopted early last year supported demand in a significant way last year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s also the case, I think, that they should have some supply-side effects.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s hard to know, it’s hard to identify those with any precision, and we hope they’re—we hope they’re very large.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You March 20, 2019 know, the idea would be that lowering corporate taxes would spur more corporate investment, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL which would spur more productivity, and lowering individual taxes would spur greater labor force participation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t want to be handing—you know, assigning credit or blame for that, but I do think that the performance of labor force participation over the last, really, three or four years has been an upside surprise that most people didn’t see coming, and it’s extremely welcome.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: Marty Crutsinger with the Associated Press.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: With the new dot plot today, you’ve gone from two rate hikes in 2019 to zero.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: You still have one showing for next year.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: The fed funds futures trading, as has been alluded to, is showing rate cuts at the end of this year.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: Are they—is that a possibility in your mind, given the sharp change you’ve made at this meeting?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, the data that we’re seeing are not currently sending a signal which suggests moving in either direction for me, which is really why we’re being patient.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We feel our policy rate is in the range of neutral.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy is growing at about trend.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation is close to target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Unemployment is under 3 percent.1 It’s a great time for us to be patient and watch and wait and see how things evolve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you mentioned the qualitative aspect of CCAR.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And U.S.—the large U.S. financial institutions have made significant progress there and are now much better at the capital planning process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And for, really, some time now, for a couple of years, we’ve talked about moving supervision of that process—moving to a supervisory approach to that rather than having a pass/fail in the stress tests.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve been talking about that for quite a while.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think, given the level that the banks have moved to in capital planning, we did that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It shouldn’t be a big surprise—something we’ve been talking about doing for a couple of years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For banks that are newer to CCAR and haven’t made that kind of progress, then they’re still going to be part of—they’re still going to have a qualitative test until they can reach similar levels of achievement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of having disparate views, I—look, we try—we are very much a consensus-driven organization.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We try very hard to reach consensus on things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the end, it’s very healthy to have disparate views and to state them publicly and put them on the record.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s nothing but healthy from my standpoint.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll always be trying to reach consensus, and, you know, I’m committed to that.

speaker: TREVOR HUNNICUTT

speaker: TREVOR HUNNICUTT

sentence: So on the household side, what we saw was a very weak reading on retail sales in December and then a bounceback in the January reading.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, it was a March 20, 2019 surprise, I would say, and inconsistent with a significant amount of other data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL dismissing it in any way, but I would go back to, what is it that supports consumer spending?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s 70 percent of the economy, as you point out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s strong economic underlying fundamentals, so, rising wages, high levels of employment, low levels of unemployment, high levels of job creation, confidence.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The household confidence surveys have moved back up to where they were last summer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we look at those fundamentals, and we think that looks like a setting in which consumption will have support from underlying economic fundamentals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s really what we’re thinking there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we’re also patiently watching and waiting and not assuming.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not taking no signal from the incoming data; that’s why we called it out in our statement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think our eyes are open on this.

sentence: Chair Powell, in 1998 the Fed eased policy in a way that some say may have avoided a recession, others say may have helped fuel the NASDAQ tech stock bubble.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And financial conditions have eased considerably this year since the policy pivot that you made clear in January.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: The S&P, for example, is just 3 percent below last summer’s peak.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And so, I wonder, does this episode from 20 years ago bear at all on your thinking today about the risks posed by rising asset values in an environment of a shallower policy path?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re in a very different world today and post-crisis, because we now very carefully monitor financial conditions and financial stability concerns on an ongoing basis, and we publish a report twice a year, and we have quarterly Board meetings and briefings where we look deeply into these things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is something we have very much on our radar screen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would say, overall, we don’t see financial stability vulnerabilities as high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are some aspects of the financial markets that we’re carefully monitoring, and those are in the March 20, 2019 nature of things that might be amplifiers to a downturn—as opposed to a financial stability Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL concern, which might lead to a financial crisis and that kind of thing, which we don’t see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we do monitor that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would also say, you know, that the whole question of monetary policy and financial stability is an unsettled and difficult one in our world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do think that the principal tools for, you know, for managing financial stability are regulation, supervision, macroprudential tools, and those sorts of things as opposed to changing the interest rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we’re certainly very mindful of financial conditions and those risks.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: If I could ask a follow-up—if it’s the case that we’re in a lower neutral interest rate world where you could have more asset price appreciation, do you think the Fed needs more macroprudential tools so that it doesn’t have to lean on monetary policy to do so much?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a very difficult question with a long answer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—in our system, we mainly rely on “through the cycle” tools like high capital and stress tests.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our financial stability system is built on those tools: high capital, high liquidity, resolution planning, stress testing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those are always on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also have some tools, like the countercyclical capital buffer, which we can deploy at times when vulnerabilities are meaningfully above normal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we do rely on those tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would say, our banks are well capitalized.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re far better capitalized and better aware of their risks and more liquid than they were before the financial crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So they’ll be more resilient in, you know, in difficult states of the economy.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Donna Borak with CNN.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Included in the President’s fiscal 2020 budget is a new estimate that the nation’s debt will balloon to more than $31 trillion over the next decade, by 2029.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: You’ve previously said that the country is on an unsustainable fiscal path.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: March 20, 2019 How alarming is that number to you?

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: And, while the United States might not be quite there yet, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL when do you begin to worry about a possible credit crisis?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do think that deficits matter, and I do think—I think it’s not really controversial to say that our debt can’t grow faster than our economy indefinitely and that’s what it’s doing now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this is something we will have to deal with, and I think we can’t really lose sight of that, and I’d like to see a greater focus on that over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not in the nature of a near-term debt crisis or anything like that, and I wouldn’t want to try to predict when that would happen, but it is something that it’s important that the public discussion really come back to, if I can say that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we will have to deal with it eventually.

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: James Politi of the Financial Times.

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: There’s huge uncertainty at the moment over the fate of the Brexit negotiations.

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: How much of a factor has this been for the Fed in turning towards a kind of patient approach to monetary policy, and what’s your base case on that?

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: And on the size of the balance sheet, what’s your—do you have a numerical estimate for where it will be at the end of September once the runoff is complete?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, of course, we’re watching Brexit carefully and hoping that it can be resolved in an orderly way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: From our standpoint, the part of it that we can control is that we’ve been involved with supervising our financial institutions that are active either in the United Kingdom or the European Union or both to make sure that they’re ready for the full range of possible outcomes to the—to Brexit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and in doing so, we’ve also had—we’ve also worked alongside regulators from the United Kingdom and the EU.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we do, again, hope that that can be resolved well, but we know that our banks are well capitalized and resilient to different kinds of events.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the size of the balance sheet, the balance sheet will be of a size of approximately 17 percent of GDP around the end of this year, down from 25 percent of GDP at the end of 2014—so, significantly smaller relative to GDP than it was.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m guessing you’re looking for a dollar number, though, probably, and that would be—so, for the size of the balance sheet, it looks like it’ll be a bit above $3.5 trillion then.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Greg Robb from MarketWatch.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Chairman Powell, could you talk through your outlook for inflation this year?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Aren’t—you’re not concerned about it?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And rising—why aren’t rising wages feeding into inflation?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let me take wages first, if I can.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So wages have moved up in the last couple of years and are now running at healthier, higher levels, and that’s a good thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, a lot of the wage gains have been going to lower-paid workers, as can happen late in the cycle, which is also a good thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but that’s not price inflation, that’s wage inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our mandate, sorry, is price inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what I see is inflation that’s close to 2 percent but that sort of keeps bumping up against 2 percent and then maybe moving back down a little bit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I don’t feel that we have kind of convincingly achieved our 2 percent mandate in a symmetrical way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, what do we mean by “symmetrical”?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we really mean is that we would look at—we know that inflation will move around on both sides of the target, and what we say is that we would be equally concerned with inflation persistently above as persistently below the target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s really our framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I don’t think we’ve quite achieved that yet, because we’re really 10 years deep in this—almost 10 years—in this expansion, and inflation is still kind of, I’d say, not, you know, clearly meeting our target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s one of the reasons why we’re being patient.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think, as I’ve said before, I think inflation that is a little bit below our target— March 20, 2019 particularly headline inflation this year will be, you know, meaningfully below our target for Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL most of the year because of lower oil prices, but we project that core will be too—that gives us the ability to be patient and not move until we see that our target goals are being achieved.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: I just wanted to press a little bit about, what is the story the Committee—you know, when you get in the discussion today and yesterday about inflation, what kind of is the story that emerges?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there are a bunch of different stories.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s no real easy answer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One of them is just that the natural rate of unemployment is lower than people think.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s one way to think about it, that there’s still more slack in the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Another is that expectations play a very—inflation expectations play a very key role in our framework and other frameworks, and, you know, there is the possibility that some people discuss of expectations being anchored but below 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so, either way, inflation itself has kind of bounced around a little below 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s the record.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: Hi, Chairman Powell.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: Thanks for the question.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: Paul Kiernan from Dow Jones Newswires.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: I’m just kind of curious—I mean, this below-target inflation is a global phenomenon, at least across advanced economies, and I’d just like to kind of hear your thoughts about what kind of challenges that poses to policymakers like yourself and the global economy in general.

speaker: PAUL KIERNAN
sentence: Yes, thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a major challenge.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s one of the major challenges of our time, really, to have inflation—you know, downward pressure on inflation, let’s say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It gives central banks less room to, you know, to respond to downturns, right?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if inflation expectations are below 2 percent, they’re always going to be pulling inflation down, and we’re going to be paddling upstream in trying to, you know, keep inflation at 2 percent, which gives us some room March 20, 2019 to cut, you know, when it’s time to cut rates when the economy weakens.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, that’s Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL something that central banks face all over the world, and we certainly face that problem too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s one of the—one of the things we’re looking into as part of our strategic monetary policy review this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The proximity to the zero lower bound calls for more creative thinking about ways we can, you know, uphold the credibility of our inflation target, and, you know, we’re open minded about ways we can do that.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Edward Lawrence from Fox Business Network.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So I counted five downgrades in the first paragraph of the FOMC statement.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: What conditions do you need to see in order for a rate cut or a rate hike on the other side of that then?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, we—I think we were—we wanted to be careful to go ahead and acknowledge the things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s relatively little hard data so far this year, but we were careful to point out lower retail sales—the weak November meeting—BFI, all those things, and I think that was the right thing to do.2 Notwithstanding that, we do have a positive outlook for the year for the reasons I mentioned—you know, solid underlying economic fundamentals, et cetera.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, and in terms of what it would take, I’d say, again, today we don’t see any—we don’t see data coming in that suggests that we should move in either direction.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They suggest that we should remain patient and let the situation clarify itself over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When the time comes, we’ll act appropriately.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: Hi.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: Matthew Boesler at Bloomberg.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: Fed Vice Chairman Rich Clarida has talked about how the decline in labor’s share of income and the corresponding high profit margins might mean that lower unemployment and higher wage growth is not flowing through to price inflation the way it used to.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: But, so far throughout this tightening cycle, the Fed 2 Chair Powell intended to point to the weak reading on retail sales for December 2018.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: March 20, 2019 has not allowed wage growth to rise above longer-term interest rates until just very recently.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: So Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL I’m wondering if, going forward, given these insights about the labor share and high profit margins and the linkage between wages and prices, would you be in favor of allowing wage growth to continue accelerating without matching that with higher interest rates?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, let me say that we’ve had, you know, a significant move up in wages and compensation over the last few years, and I—which does not trouble me from the standpoint of inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve had—also had—in other cycles, we’ve had situations where, you know, unit labor costs were moving up above inflation, and that didn’t lead to price inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It does—you know, in theory, it can squeeze corporate margins, and, you know, that can’t go on indefinitely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, nonetheless, I don’t see the current wage picture as concerning from an inflation standpoint.

speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER
sentence: More generally, to the extent that wage growth in excess of interest rates allows households to pay down debt faster, whereas interest rates in excess of wage growth risks a further buildup in debt, how do you account for the sort of financial stability consequences of varying interest rates relative to wage growth?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think we look at—I understand what you’re asking, but we’re looking at—our mandate is price inflation and maximum employment, and that’s what we’re looking at with setting interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we also monitor financial stability very carefully across all meaningful asset categories.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think we tie it particularly to the relationship you’re talking about.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Nancy Marshall-Genzer with Marketplace.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Just a quick follow-up on Brexit.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: You mentioned that you’re making sure that U.S. financial institutions are ready for whatever outcome.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: I’m wondering, can you be a little more specific March 20, 2019 about that?

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: And also, how are you preparing for any pressures that a hard Brexit would put on Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the U.S. dollar?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, as I mentioned, you know, with the stress tests that the largest financial institutions—and those are the ones that tend to be active internationally—that they undergo every year, we put them through very large financial shocks with large losses and big changes in markets every year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we vary that every year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s a pretty good—you know, having done that for a number of years now, that’s—and having them be required to have adequate capital and liquidity even after all that happens.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s a good thing to have done, knowing that you’re going into something that’s quite unknown, which may prove stressful, it may not prove stressful, depending on what the outcome is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think all that has probably prepared our institutions well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That said, nothing like this has happened in recent years, and so it’s really hard to be confident.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re very watchful about what’s going on.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: And as far as the dollar goes?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we don’t—you know, we—the dollar is really the business of the Treasury Department.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s certainly a financial condition unto itself that plays into our models, but we don’t, you know, seek or model or attempt to affect the dollar directly with our policies.

speaker: JOHN HELTMAN
sentence: Hi.

speaker: JOHN HELTMAN
sentence: John Heltman—John Heltman with American Banker.

speaker: JOHN HELTMAN
sentence: I have a question about the Fed’s proposal from October of last year regarding enhanced prudential standards for banks above $250 billion.

speaker: JOHN HELTMAN
sentence: Some analysts have suggested that that proposal could encourage consolidation mergers and acquisition among banks, particularly at the upper end of the range.

speaker: JOHN HELTMAN
sentence: I’m curious if the Fed anticipated that outcome and whether you have any reservations or whether you—the Fed cares about bank consolidation more generally.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not motivated by a particular view of industry structure that we’re trying to achieve through our regulation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we want to have banks of all different sizes and with different business models out there carrying out their functions in the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we think about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would also say, when banks merge and move into a larger asset category, they get stronger regulation, not weaker regulation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you think about it, you know, if you’re a medium-sized bank and you merge with another medium-sized bank, you wind up being more than a medium-sized bank, you know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the sense of our tapering is that—“tailoring,” sorry—our tailoring policy is that the highest expectations fall upon the largest, most systemically important, most complex institutions, and then at every step along the way, the expectations become more tailored to the risks that that institution actually presents to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So— BRIAN CHEUNG.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Brian Cheung with Yahoo Finance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks for taking my question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So as the Fed remains on pause, does the central bank find the onus on fiscal policy to extend its economic recovery and fend off a slowdown—as in, is the Fed positioning itself to take on a reactionary role to whatever fiscal policy is doing?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m asking because we’re seeing the waning effect of tax reform and no material news on infrastructure, so just wondering kind of how you feel the monetary policy–fiscal policy balance is in swing right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we take—we take fiscal policy as, you know, as exogenous to what we do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, in other words, whatever happens with fiscal policy, we take that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t evaluate it, we don’t criticize it, and we don’t overreact to it either.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think it’s just a fact.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just an external fact about the economy for us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, our policy is—the reason we’re March 20, 2019 on hold is that we think our policy rate is in a good place, and we think the economy is in a good Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL place, and we’re watching carefully as we see these events evolve around the world and at home, and we think that’s what we need to be doing.

speaker: STEVEN BECKNER
sentence: Steve Beckner, freelance journalist reporting for NPR, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: STEVEN BECKNER
sentence: The Fed has been allowing the average maturity of securities in its bond portfolio to lengthen.

speaker: STEVEN BECKNER
sentence: Is this aimed at—consciously aimed at flattening the yield curve, and is that going to be part of the Fed’s longer-run balance sheet strategy?

speaker: STEVEN BECKNER
sentence: And if flattening the yield curve is a conscious long-term strategy, are you concerned about the side effect of the heightening concerns about a flatter or inverted yield curve being a harbinger of recession?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The basic answer to your question is “no.” We are—the decision about the maturity composition of the Fed’s balance sheet in the longer run lies ahead of us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have not made that decision, and we’re—we really haven’t begun to have a serious series of discussions over a series of meetings to grapple with that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That, I think, will be something we turn to reasonably soon, but I think it will take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a consequential decision and one that needs some thought.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve had a lot of balance sheet discussions, as I mentioned, over the last four meetings, but this is the next big one that—big decision that we’ll face.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, I think we’re not going to be in a rush to resolve it, but we’ll turn to it soon.

speaker: STEVEN BECKNER
sentence: Can I just follow up, please?

speaker: STEVEN BECKNER
sentence: Well, how do you account for the fact that the average maturity has in fact been lengthening and contributing to a flattening of the yield curve?

speaker: STEVEN BECKNER
sentence: Is that—what’s—what’s causing that?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think, isn’t it just that as securities roll off, you wind up investing in—you know, as a 10-year rolls off, you wind up investing in a 10-year, and automatically that March 20, 2019 lengthens things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not at all a plan to lengthen the balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just been—we try to Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL have a practice that we don’t deviate from, and it’s transparent, and—no policy message in that.

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: Hi, Jean Yung with Market News.

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: I wanted to ask, at what point do you expect to begin to allow the balance sheet to grow slowly again?

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: What are—how will you make that decision?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as I—as I mentioned, the balance sheet runoff will stop at about—at September 30.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if it is our view at that time that we’re still a ways away from—a ways above a balance sheet that is what we need to efficiently and effectively conduct monetary policy, at that time we will hold the balance sheet constant.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then what’ll happen is, organically, very gradually, currency and other nonreserved liabilities will grow, and reserves will shrink.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the question you’re asking is, how long will that go on?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The truth is, we don’t know, and we don’t really know that we’ll move past September 30th.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The level of reserve demand is something that we’ve put a lot of effort and time into creating estimates, based on market intelligence and surveys and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The truth is, we don’t know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It may evolve over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ll just have to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t want to put a time out there for that, but—so I’ll just leave it there.

speaker: COURTENAY BROWN
sentence: Hi, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: COURTENAY BROWN
sentence: Courtenay Brown from Axios.

speaker: COURTENAY BROWN
sentence: Are you concerned at all what the market impact will be should the Fed resume policy tightening somewhere down the line?

speaker: COURTENAY BROWN
sentence: As I’m sure you know, the market listens to you very, very closely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I’m just going to say that I think we’re in a good place right now, which is, we’re being patient, we’re watching, we don’t see any data pushing us to March 20, 2019 move rates in either direction, and we’re going to watch carefully and patiently as we allow Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL events to evolve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And when they do clarify, we will act appropriately.
